author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Braces for School Return Amid Fears of Virus Spike
description: Can Britain reopen its schools safely? The Tory government is confident it can, but after an exam grading fiasco, trust in the government is running low.
content: LONDON — When pupils return to Southend High School For Boys next week, the cafeteria will serve takeout food only and lunch will be eaten outside. Lessons will stretch to two-and-a-half hours to reduce the need to switch classrooms. And new equipment has been bought to spray the sports changing rooms with disinfectant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Astead W. Herndon
title: Biden’s Approval Rating, G.O.P. Recasts Trump: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: President Trump, during his convention speech, did little to acknowledge the coronavirus pandemic, warning instead of what would become of the country’s economy and “greatness” if Joe Biden were elected.
content: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Your Coronavirus Test Is Positive. Maybe It Shouldn’t Be.
description: The usual diagnostic tests may simply be too sensitive and too slow to contain the spread of the virus.
content: Some of the nation’s leading public health experts are raising a new concern in the endless debate over coronavirus testing in the United States: The standard tests are diagnosing huge numbers of people who may be carrying relatively insignificant amounts of the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Rosa
title: After 90 Years, Columbia Takes Slave Owner’s Name Off a Dorm
description: Samuel Bard was George Washington’s doctor and delivered Alexander Hamilton’s first son. He was also a “pretty significant slave owner.”
content: Little is known about the 18th-century New Yorker described in an advertisement seeking the return of a runaway slave in 1776 beyond his given name (James), what he looked like (tall and thin, with bloodshot eyes) and that he was talkative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Trump’s Strategy: Make ‘Wobbly Republicans’ Think Their Party Is Great Again
description: The Trump campaign wants to lure back moderates who believe that the president has lurched too far right and openly courted extremists.
content: President Trump and his party are entering the nine-week stretch until Election Day with their success riding on a hope that enough voters come to the following conclusion: You’re not as bad as we thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christiaan Mader, Rick Rojas and Will Wright
title: In One Louisiana City, a Police Shooting, a Pandemic and a Hurricane
description: In Lafayette, La., frustration and fatigue set in after storms, a pandemic and now a fatal police shooting that some residents believe is being overshadowed.
content: LAFAYETTE, La. — Trayford Pellerin was killed in a barrage of police gunfire outside a convenience store. Within hours, the kind of unrest sparked in other cities by fatal confrontations between African-Americans and law enforcement began bubbling up in Lafayette.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Carol Rosenberg
title: C.I.A. Uncensors Memoir of F.B.I. Agent Who Protested Torture of Terrorists
description: Nine years after the C.I.A. blacked out parts of Ali Soufan’s book, the agency has finally allowed a more complete version of his story to be published.
content: WASHINGTON — After a group of Qaeda suspects was captured in September 2002, the C.I.A. flew Ali Soufan, an experienced F.B.I. counterterrorism agent, to Afghanistan to help interrogate them. But when he arrived, C.I.A. officials abruptly sent word to keep him from the two most significant new detainees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Get Duked!’ and NASCAR
description: Four teenagers try to escape the Scottish Highlands alive in “Get Duked!” And NASCAR’s regular season finale kicks off in Daytona.
content: GET DUKED! (2019) Stream on Amazon. Three troublemaking teenagers and a strait-laced loner head out on a character-building camping excursion in the Scottish Highlands — what could go wrong? In this film, from the music-video director Ninian Doff, the boys encounter trouble in the form of a homicidal couple (played by Eddie Izzard and Georgie Glen) armed and hellbent on maintaining “the integrity of the species.” In her New York Times review, Manohla Dargis wrote that “the movie is loud, busy and cheerfully glib, though at one point — after the weapons and politics have been brandished — it takes a brief turn to sincerity.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: A Final Episode for the TV Listings
description: The Times will no longer include the programming lineup in its print edition, ending an eight-decade run.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 29, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 29, 2020.
content: Because of an editing error, a picture caption with an article on Page 4 about the golden age of televised theater misidentifies the production company for “Twelve Angry Men.” It was Studio One, not Playhouse 90.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘Panting for Air’ Under Smoky Western Skies
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 29, 2020.
content: “It was one patient after another, every 15 minutes, wheezing, unable to sleep. It’s terrible.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon, Sarah Mervosh and Richard A. Oppel Jr
title: Jacob Blake Was Shackled in Hospital Bed After Police Shot Him
description: The authorities said an earlier sexual assault charge was the reason for the restraints, which were removed on Friday.
content: KENOSHA, Wis. — Days after a Kenosha police officer shot Jacob Blake outside an apartment building, the authorities on Friday provided new details on what led up to the videotaped encounter that has prompted heated street protests and calls for reform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch and Edgar Sandoval
title: 16 Injured in Bus Accident Near Port Authority
description: One person was critically hurt after a New Jersey Transit bus struck a barrier on a ramp at 39th Street and Ninth Avenue in Manhattan, the authorities said.
content: Sixteen people were hurt, one critically, in a bus crash on a ramp near the Port Authority terminal in Manhattan on Saturday morning, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Desmond
title: When the Threat of Eviction Meets the Threat of the Virus
description: A deadly pandemic is no time to turn families out of their homes.
content: A year and a half ago, Jhon Loaiza and his wife, Sugey Bedoya, moved with their three daughters — now 12, 5 and 3 — from a two-bedroom apartment in New York City to a compact brick ranch house in San Antonio. They loved that house — its fenced-in backyard and four whole bedrooms, each with soft tan carpet — and their new city. They would walk by the river with ice cream or ride bikes after Sunday church. At night, Mr. Loaiza would put on salsa or reggaeton, twirling his girls around the living room and laughing. His broad smile forced his dimples to crease in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Many Want to Be Japan’s New Leader. Do They Know What Awaits Them?
description: The coronavirus, a tanking economy, an aggressive China, a postponed Olympics, a U.S. election: That’s just the start. And any successor will confront those challenges without having the stature of Shinzo Abe.
content: TOKYO — The Japanese economy has taken a historic nosedive. The coronavirus could yet rage out of control and force a second postponement of the Olympics. Chinese military aggression is rising in the region just as America, Japan’s closest ally, is embroiled in a polarizing presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: College Football Is Not Essential
description: Why are some schools pressuring student-athletes to play a game that could expose them to the coronavirus?
content: For more than six months now, many workers deemed essential have had to strap on face masks for shifts at meatpacking plants, Walmarts, grocery stores, hardware stores and restaurants. It is a necessary sacrifice for the nation’s well-being. But at universities across the country, while scores of professors, staff and students start the academic year remotely to curb the spread of the coronavirus, another class of worker will be asked to strap on protective gear to do their job — without the face coverings: college football players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Julian E. Barnes
title: No More In-Person Election Briefings for Congress, Intelligence Chief Says
description: Lawmakers in both parties worry the move will block their ability to question and test intelligence assessments that can be crucial to ensuring that foreign powers do not undermine election results.
content: The nation’s top intelligence officials moved on Saturday to tighten control over the flow of sensitive intelligence about foreign threats to November’s election, telling Congress that they would no longer provide in-person briefings about election security and would rely solely on written updates instead.
source.name: The New York Times

title: California Surpasses 700,000 Coronavirus Cases Even as Its Outbreak Slows
description: Some in Europe fear a return to lockdowns as cases rise. Colleges struggle to rein in sororities and fraternities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze and Melissa Eddy
title: Berlin Police Halt March Against Coronavirus Restrictions, Saying Protesters Risked Spreading Disease
description: Thousands had gathered in the German capital. But the march was shut down after an hour for failing to obey social distancing rules.
content: BERLIN — Thousands of Germans angered over restrictions intended to control the coronavirus marched in Berlin on Saturday, but the police dispersed them after an hour because many were violating the very social-distancing rules championed by Chancellor Angela Merkel that they say threaten their rights and livelihoods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: ‘That Same Feeling’: Painful Memories in Kenosha Come Rushing Back
description: The auto plant closed in 1988, turning the Wisconsin city upside down. Now it’s facing an even deeper existential crisis.
content: KENOSHA, Wis. — Anguished residents wondered if their city would ever recover. The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson came to town and called for justice. An outraged Wisconsin governor vowed to make things right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch and Allyson Waller
title: Bison Are On the Run After 125 Escape a Nebraska Feedlot
description: So many people have been chasing the 50 stragglers that the animals got spooked and split off into singles and pairs, complicating efforts to catch them, a sheriff said.
content: After more than 100 bison escaped from a feedlot in southern Nebraska, local residents hopped into pickup trucks and onto horses and four-wheelers to try to catch the fleeing animals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kramon
title: Now Is the Time to Start Keeping a Journal
description: It can be like therapy, only cheaper, and provides a chronicle of our times.
content: Looking for a way to relax in these tense times? A way to know yourself better? To improve your writing and the stories you tell others about yourself? To create something that outlasts you? And for psychotherapy, on the cheap? What better time than now to start writing a journal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristin Merrilees and Amy Lombard
title: Christmas Time Is … Here?
description: On TikTok, the holiday spirit has come early.
content: Hannah Smith is “usually not one of those people who gets excited about Christmas in July,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: The Lawbreakers Trump Loves
description: He uses scare tactics about “law and order.” But what distinguishes this White House is its ties to criminals.
content: Even as President Trump accepted the Republican presidential nomination on the White House lawn, lawbreakers rampaged through the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Texas Isaiah and Akwaeke Emezi
title: Intimacy in Isolation
description: It can be unsettling to be seen. Now I have to see myself.
content: I have been alone for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jean Guerrero
title: Stephen Miller’s Dystopian America
description: Language is a tool for shaping minds, and Miller knows how to weaponize it.
content: Over the past week, the Republican National Convention sought to conjure a “radical left” hellscape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Generic Rivalry
description: Michael Hawkins leaves us stranded on a corner.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Another day, another themeless Hawkins puzzle to drive us crazy. (For a fun fact, don’t miss the Constructor Notes.) Michael Hawkins is familiar, with plenty of grids under his belt including a good crunchy Saturday back in July. Today’s puzzle has a lot of offbeat elements to it that made for a pleasant ski run for me, until I skidded on the ice in the southeast corner, flew into the woods and had to wait for a dog to dig me out, the mental equivalent of what happens when I draw enough blanks that I have to leave a puzzle alone for a while. Where does that good dog come from?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: Staying Afloat: A Pandemic Financial Guide for Millennials
description: Younger people were hit particularly hard by the economic crisis. Whether or not you were greatly affected, here are ways to manage your finances during the pandemic.
content: Several months into the coronavirus crisis, millions of Americans are still suffering from the economic fallout. Younger people are in an especially tough spot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Denying Alex Rodriguez, Mets Avoid a Risky Presence in the Owner’s Box
description: There’s no denying his charm and genuine passion for baseball. But his habit of overstepping boundaries would have made him an uncomfortable presence if he had succeeded in purchasing the Mets.
content: From the very start, Alex Rodriguez has been an achiever. He was the first overall draft pick at 17 years old and a batting champion at 21. He was the richest player in baseball at 25 and a three-time most valuable player at 32.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu and Michael Levenson
title: ‘Black Panther’ Star Chadwick Boseman Dies of Cancer at 43
description: The actor also played groundbreaking figures like James Brown, Jackie Robinson and Thurgood Marshall, becoming one of his generation’s most sought-after leading men.
content: Chadwick Boseman, the regal actor who embodied a long-held dream of African-American moviegoers as the star of the groundbreaking superhero film “Black Panther,” died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 43.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon draw our attention to a foible.
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s excerpt is a thinker. At first, I didn’t easily reconcile its content with its author, whom I admire but know for only one reason (which proves the excerpt’s point, to get meta). After reading an expanded version, I absorbed the meaning a bit better, and I now find it very timely and profound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Rory McIlroy and Patrick Cantlay Tough It Out, Sharing BMW Lead
description: The two were the only golfers to finish below par after 36 holes. Tiger Woods was far back in the field as he struggled to keep his PGA Tour season alive.
content: OLYMPIA FIELDS, Ill. — Rory McIlroy doesn’t need fans to help him keep his head in the game at the BMW Championship. Olympia Fields is so tough that it won’t allow anything but his full attention on every shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano
title: How to Forge a Solid Parent-Teacher Relationship
description: This year is ‘almost like a full reset. A horrible reset, but a full reset.’
content: During a usual school year, Maria Davis-Pierre is one of those parents who regularly reach out to their children’s teachers. A mother of three in Lake Worth, Fla., and the founder of the parenting organization Autism in Black, Ms. Davis-Pierre checks in monthly via email and requests meetings upon receiving progress reports, working with her kids’ teachers to make sure that her eldest daughter especially — who is 8 and on the autism spectrum — is meeting her goals and getting the most from her schooling. “Especially for Black parents, we have to let them know that we’re involved,” Ms. Davis-Pierre said. “We want to know what’s going on.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: It’s Hard to Make Dignity Interesting. Chadwick Boseman Found a Way.
description: The actor, who died Friday at 43, exploded the parameters of what biographical moviemaking ought to be.
content: The problem with dignity is that there’s not much an actor can do with it. Not when he’s playing Jackie Robinson or Thurgood Marshall, not when you’re the leader of a made-up African kingdom, like Wakanda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney and Sydney Ember
title: How the G.O.P. Stretched Hard to Defend Trump on Race and Gender
description: Never before has a convention by a major party felt compelled to call such a diverse array of speakers to defend the character of a sitting president.
content: The Republican convention this week marked an extraordinary effort to recast President Trump’s image on issues of race and gender, with the party stretching to find African-Americans who would testify that Mr. Trump is not racist, and lining up women to describe him as sensitive and empathetic — qualities he rarely displays in public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez and Richard Fausset
title: Hurricane Laura Was Powerful, but Louisiana Was Prepared
description: In 2005, Hurricane Rita leveled some coastal communities in southwest Louisiana, forcing changes to building codes and attitudes. As Laura approached, the region was ready.
content: CARLYSS, La. — Karla Broussard was standing under the awning of her liquor store on Friday, to stay dry in the rain. All around her the town of Carlyss was a mess. Hurricane Laura had not been kind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Berkman
title: N.B.A. Brings Flash to E-Sports, but Can It Hold On to Its Viewers?
description: Despite challenges, the N.B.A. continues to build its e-sports program, saying it generates sponsorship revenue and provides valuable data on viewing habits of cord-cutters.
content: Since its introduction two years ago, the National Basketball Association’s e-sports arm has struggled to draw viewers. Then, with Americans forced to shelter in place in early March, the N.B.A. had a captive audience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Julia Carmel
title: Chadwick Boseman, Who Starred in ‘Black Panther,’ Is Mourned as a ‘Superhero’
description: Oprah Winfrey and Joseph R. Biden Jr. were among those who praised the actor, who died on Friday at 43, for his portrayals of Black leaders and his perseverance against cancer.
content: After the announcement late Friday that the “Black Panther” star Chadwick Boseman had died, tributes began pouring in on social media from prominent figures in entertainment, politics and beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Enjoy That Last Gasp of Summer
description: Tired of your routine? With the unofficial final weekend of the season on its way, here are seven ways to step up your leisure game.
content: Movies have always been escapist: During the Great Depression, audiences flocked to cinemas in an attempt to forget their worries, at least for a while. Today, as the pandemic continues, drive-in theaters have been popping up all over. In Astoria, Queens, the Bel Aire Diner started one in its parking lot, while Walmart has turned parking lots at 160 of its Supercenter locations into outdoor movie theaters with free showings through Oct. 21.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arvin Ahmadi
title: From Iran to America, One Epic Tale at a Time
description: A modern-day Scheherazade uses storytelling to survive the fifth grade.
content: When I was growing up, my bedtime stories involved great warriors and kings, the heroes of ancient Persia. Many came from the “Shahnameh,” an epic Persian poem that weaves the history of Iran like a colorful tapestry. In “Everything Sad Is Untrue,” Daniel Nayeri weaves an equally rich history of his family’s journey from Iran to America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Sydney Ember
title: Biden, Speaking to National Guard Group, Takes Aim at Republican Criticism on Crime
description: The Democratic presidential nominee hit back at attacks delivered at the Republican National Convention.
content: After a Republican National Convention week in which President Trump and his allies sought to brand Joseph R. Biden Jr. as radically anti-law enforcement, the Democratic nominee took implicit aim at that characterization in his own remarks on Saturday as he swiped at Mr. Trump’s calls for “law and order” and ripped the president’s record as commander in chief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Splaining How Government Works to Young Voters
description: Ben Sheehan runs a nonprofit that uses humor for civic education.
content: Name: Ben Sheehan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: All Aflutter
description: Olivia Mitra Framke’s puzzle has subtle and unpredictable ramifications.
content: *Important note for electronic solvers: The center box of this puzzle, which falls between 62- and 63-Across, is notably shaded gray in the print version, which makes it stand out from the beginning of the solve. This small difference alters the whole feel of working the puzzle, which is kind of confusing but appropriate, as you will see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Film Crew Spent 3 Years in Remote Balkan Hamlet. Will They Ever Leave?
description: Nominated for two Oscars, “Honeyland” charted the tensions between a hermitic beekeeper and her disorderly neighbors. Now the filmmakers are struggling to disentangle themselves from their subjects.
content: BEKIRLIJA, North Macedonia — When the producer and two directors of “Honeyland” returned to the setting of their documentary in North Macedonia for the first time since it earned two Oscar nominations in February, something fundamental had changed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Marcus
title: What It’s Like to Be an R.A. Now
description: Dorm life got kinda serious.
content: Resident advisers have always played a key role in how colleges implement behavioral policies. An R.A. will typically oversee a dormitory floor or building; they are responsible for limiting parties and helping new students settle in. At some schools, R.A.s are trained in how to help prevent sexual assault. Now, colleges have drafted them to another front line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Fashion Advertisers Rediscover Black Models
description: In the fall ad campaigns, race-conscious casting now matters. Is it progress, or is it cynicism?
content: Nearly a decade ago, when Precious Lee arrived for a modeling go-see, she was grilled about her ethnic background. The clients, who were representing a deep-pocketed luxury brand, were looking for a mixed-race model, Ms. Lee recalled. When she told them that she was Black, their faces fell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Goodnough
title: Trump Program to Cover Uninsured Covid-19 Patients Falls Short of Promise
description: Some patients are still receiving staggering bills. Others don’t qualify because conditions other than Covid-19 were their primary diagnosis.
content: WASHINGTON — Marilyn Cortez, a retired cafeteria worker in Houston with no health insurance, spent much of July in the hospital with Covid-19. When she finally returned home, she received a $36,000 bill that compounded the stress of her illness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivy Manners
title: Wedding Presents That Will Turn Any House Into a Home
description: Industry experts share their favorite gifts that are sure to warm any couple’s hearts and home.
content: For many couples, the moment they announce their newly engaged status, questions like, “When is the wedding?” and “Where are you registered?” are sure to follow. Creating a gift registry has become an obligatory (and sometimes overwhelming) part of planning a wedding. And, for family and friends, it can sometimes feel as if there’s a fine art to picking the perfect gift that is both practical and special. We asked a few industry pros — from a celebrity planner to a celebrated fashion designer — for their favorite wedding gifts. Here are a few of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: ‘Enough Is Enough’: New Racial Justice Leaders Rise in Kenosha
description: A new crop of activists has joined the ranks of protesters in Kenosha, Wis., as police killings across the country spur ordinary people into the streets. Jacob Blake’s family spoke at a rally on Saturday.
content: KENOSHA, Wis. — He walked near the front of the march in Kenosha, Wis., on Saturday, a trail of hundreds of demonstrators behind him, raising a black-gloved fist in the air. His white Chicago Bulls shorts flopped past his knees and the gold block letters on his black T-shirt glistened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.C. Shilton
title: Have a New Address? Don’t Lose Your Mail
description: If you’ve decided to temporarily relocate, make sure your essential correspondence and eagerly anticipated packages can find you.
content: With many employers allowing staffers to work remotely well into 2021, you may be considering a temporary move. Perhaps you have relatives who need help with child care, or elderly parents to look after. Or maybe, if you’re going to be all alone for the next few months anyway, you’ve decided having deer as neighbors in a tiny house in the woods sounds better than communing with the roaches in your apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janet Maslin
title: A Python Ate the President’s Neighbor? Only in Carl Hiaasen’s Florida
description: “Squeeze Me,” Hiaasen’s new novel, is an unabashedly political satire full of his signature high jinks.
content: Back in 2016, when reality TV stars were still funny, Carl Hiaasen wrote a book, “Razor Girl,” taking aim at some. They were the Nance brothers, an ersatz crew of bayou types who actually came from a wealthy Milwaukee suburb and had to be coached to sound like Cajuns (except for the racial and ethnic slurs, which they had down pat). The book holds up even though its “Duck Dynasty” muses have moved on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Deciding Who Gets to Live in the Family Home During a Divorce
description: A long-term plan for separate lives is the wisest choice for all parties.
content: Q: My husband and I recently decided to separate after many years together. Because we jointly own the house and are both named on the mortgage, I believe we should each be entitled to time living alone there. (Our children are grown, so there are no custody issues.) My husband disagrees and refuses to leave our home for any amount of time. Since I own half the house, do I have the legal right to have it to myself half of the time?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Dead Dolphins Wash Ashore After Oil Spill Off Mauritius
description: The deaths have added to growing concern that the spill could be disastrous for Mauritius, a tiny island nation off Africa’s eastern coast that is highly dependent on fishing and tourism.
content: Environmentalists are expressing alarm over an increasing number of dead dolphins that have washed ashore on Mauritius after a Japanese ship ran aground last month, spilling oil into the famed blue lagoons off the Indian Ocean island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Alcorn and Video by Mohamed Sadek for The New York Times
title: What Is Waacking, and Why Is It All Over TikTok?
description: A few dedicated New Yorkers are masters of the 1970s club dance, which has become a social media sensation.
content: Princess Lockerooo is a whirling force with a singular focus: spreading the gospel of waacking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Humans Take a Step Closer to ‘Flying Cars’
description: A Japanese company said it had completed a manned flight of its electrical vertical takeoff and landing machine. Experts say the technology needs work and that it will be expensive.
content: In the 1880s, the first automobile was developed and about two decades later, the Wright brothers in North Carolina invented the first successful airplane. Today, the world is closer to combining those two concepts as a Japanese tech company said it completed a manned test flight of a “flying car.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danya Issawi
title: Talking About Racism With The Times’s Youngest Readers
description: When editors of The New York Times for Kids put together a package about race, their driving priority was simple: Put kids’ experiences first.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Goodman
title: Where to Stream Chadwick Boseman’s Best Performances
description: The star made a specialty of playing Black heroes real (Jackie Robinson, Thurgood Marshall) and imaginary (Black Panther).
content: Chadwick Boseman, the actor who died Friday at 43, made his mark as a Hollywood leading man in just seven short years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Djokovic and Other Top Men Are Creating a Players’ Association
description: It is not clear whether the group will operate like a union, although it was billed that way to get players to join. Women are not being included.
content: Frustrated by what they view as a lack of leverage in men’s tennis, Novak Djokovic and Vasek Pospisil are forming a breakaway body to represent the interests of male players outside of the current structure of the Association of Tennis Professionals, and have resigned their leadership roles in the association’s player council.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ideas for Better Political Debates
description: Get rid of moderators? Use a chess clock? Hold them virtually? Eliminate debates altogether? Readers offer their suggestions.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Mizell
title: Why Does the W.N.B.A. #SayHerName? Ask Angel McCoughtry
description: McCoughtry, a star veteran on the Las Vegas Aces, has been praised for suggesting that the W.N.B.A. include Breonna Taylor’s name on its jerseys.
content: Whenever a W.N.B.A. team steps on the floor during the 2020 season, Angel McCoughtry’s influence is there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur, Raymond Zhong and David McCabe
title: TikTok Deal Is Complicated by New Rules From China Over Tech Exports
description: In an 11th-hour twist, Beijing raised a potential hurdle for a sale of TikTok, further roiling the race to buy the Chinese-owned app.
content: As the sale of TikTok enters its final stages, Beijing is saying it wants the last word.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Catching the Buzz: A Young C.E.O. on Her Lemonade Business, Which Was Inspired by Bees
description: Mikaila Ulmer’s “Bee Fearless” is that rarest of book breeds: the middle grade memoir.
content: A little more than halfway through “Bee Fearless,” the 10-year-old C.E.O. Mikaila Ulmer has her first encounter with a fancy advertising agency. Its experts love the mission of her lemonade business and wonder if they can help. She takes the meeting, and a designer lets her in on a secret: “It’s not the product you sell but the story you tell.” And so we get this rarest of book breeds: the middle grade start-up memoir, by a teenager.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Hotz
title: How to Meet New People, Even at a Distance
description: Online and offline platforms are helping strangers form social connections, which are crucial for our health, especially in a pandemic.
content: A retired teacher, a Midwestern minister and a mother of two teenagers all dial into a Zoom room. For the next 90 minutes, they do something their typical adult lives don’t usually afford them a chance to do: listen to others’ perspectives, and have others listen to them. And after three rounds of answering not-so-standard questions, like “What sense of purpose guides you in your life?”, the group leaves the room, feeling deeply connected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Is Teleprompter Trump Effective?
description: Although most voters complain about President Trump’s often abrasive personality, Americans over all are actually far more likely to say they’re bothered by his personal foibles than by his politics.
content: Welcome to Poll Watch, our weekly look at polling data and survey research on the candidates, voters and issues that will shape the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright, Rick Rojas and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Trump Visits Storm-Ravaged Lake Charles, a Louisiana City Still Without Power
description: President Trump met with state and local officials in Louisiana and Texas after Hurricane Laura devastated the region. Many people still have no electricity or running water.
content: LAKE CHARLES, La. — Days after Hurricane Laura slammed into Louisiana, hundreds of thousands of people remained without electricity on Saturday, with the situation especially dire in Lake Charles, a city near the coastline where nearly all 80,000 residents have been without power for days and many have no running water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: ‘Something Broke Inside Belarusians.’ Why an Apolitical People Rose Up
description: Comfortable urban elites long tolerated the eccentricities of the country’s ruler, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko. Then came the coronavirus and a blatantly falsified presidential election.
content: MINSK, Belarus — Denis Dudinsky, the longhaired and mustachioed host of “Good Morning Belarus!,” can still hear the producer’s nervous voice in his ear any time his banter approached something remotely political.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Sarah Palin’s Suit Against New York Times Will Go to Trial, Judge Rules
description: The Times’s attempt to bring the case to a close was denied, and a federal judge set a Feb. 1 date to weigh Ms. Palin’s defamation lawsuit over an editorial.
content: A federal judge said on Friday that there was enough evidence in Sarah Palin’s defamation lawsuit against The New York Times Company to send it to a jury trial, a victory for the former vice-presidential candidate and governor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo and Hilary Moss
title: Wander Through Animal Crossing and Catfish Row
description: As summer recedes, check out a comedy show inside a Nintendo game, get teary at ‘Porgy and Bess’ and catch a Ray Bradbury read-a-thon.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: N.B.A. Protest Shows Who Calls the Shots in a Superstar Economy
description: Professional basketball players demonstrated the enormous power of highly paid workers with rare skills, but also their caution.
content: Like a vintage LeBron James dunk, the pro basketball labor stoppage was remarkable both for its display of strength and for the speed with which it ended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck, Annie Karni and Alexander Burns
title: Rival Themes Emerge as Race Enters Final Weeks: Covid vs. Law and Order
description: The national political conventions over the last two weeks set the battle lines for the election’s remaining weeks. Joe Biden is focusing on President Trump’s virus management, while the president is hammering a law-and-order message.
content: As a weeklong Republican offensive against Joseph R. Biden Jr. ends, the Democratic nominee plans to resume campaigning in swing states and has released a multimillion dollar barrage of ads attacking President Trump’s handling of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hisako Ueno and Mike Ives
title: Shinzo Abe’s Resignation Prompts Speculation About His Successor
description: Whoever the Liberal Democratic Party elects as its leader, probably within the next week, will almost certainly become Japan’s next prime minister. It isn’t clear who that will be.
content: TOKYO — In his resignation speech on Friday, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said that the executives of his conservative political party were finalizing plans for selecting a new leader. Speculation about who that might be was swirling even before he took the podium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devin Oktar Yalkin and Lora Kelley
title: Conventions to Match a Surreal Year
description: A photographer tries to find the moments of stillness.
content: This year’s conventions were not typical ones for photographers to shoot. Absent the massive crowds, bustling auditoriums and balloon fanfare of conventions past, they were left staring at candidates through a screen.
source.name: The New York Times

title: You Need This Summery Succotash
description: Make Vallery Lomas’s dish, or any of the most popular recipes of the week.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include Vallery Lomas’s succotash with sausage and shrimp (above), Yewande Komolafe’s crispy bean cakes with harissa, lemon and herbs and Melissa Clark’s crème fraîche poundcake. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Kornei
title: Did Something Burp? It Was an Earthquake
description: Years of observations in central Italy show that more carbon dioxide percolates through Earth’s crust during periods of strong seismic activity.
content: During earthquakes, spider webs of faults open up below ground, allowing gases deep within our planet to percolate upward. Researchers have now compiled the first long-term record that shows a relationship between earthquakes and the release of carbon dioxide gas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: The Princess vs. the Portrait in Trumpworld
description: The first family serves up a malarkey buffet.
content: WASHINGTON — As long as the Trumps were hijacking the White House for their convention finale, they may as well have built a golden escalator from the Truman Balcony to the South Lawn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: What to Know About Colon Cancer
description: The cancer that killed Chadwick Boseman is the second-leading cause of cancer deaths in the United States, and rates are rising among younger people.
content: In the wake of Chadwick Boseman’s death from colon cancer at age 43, many people have questions about the disease, especially about the risk of colon cancer in younger people. Here’s what is known and what experts recommend.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Compare Pages From an Uncensored Book on Investigating Terrorism
source.name: The New York Times
